title: 103_s1952
content:
The United States Botanic Garden Commemorative Coin Act of 1995 specifies the coin's design and purpose. The Secretary of the Treasury shall issue not more than 500,000 $1 silver coins, weighing 26.73 grams, with a diameter of 1.5 inches, containing 90% silver and 10% copper. The design of the coins shall feature a rose, the national floral emblem, and a frontal view of the French facade of the United States. The coins issued under this Act shall feature a rose, the national floral emblem, and a frontal view of the French facade of the United States Botanic Garden. Each coin will have inscriptions of the coin's value, the year '1995', and the words 'Liberty', 'In God We Trust', 'United States of America', and 'E Pluribus Unum'. The coins issued will be legal tender. The coins issued under this Act in 1995 shall bear inscriptions of the words 'Liberty', 'In God We Trust', 'United States of America', and 'E Pluribus Unum', and will be legal tender. The Secretary shall obtain silver for the coins minted under this Act only from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. Selection of design for the coins is specified. The design for the coins authorized by this Act shall be selected by the Secretary after consultation with the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden and the Commission of Fine Arts. The design shall also be reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. The issuance of coins is also specified. The Act authorizes the issuance of coins in uncirculated and proof qualities, minted at a designated Mint facility. The Secretary may issue coins minted under this Act from January 1, 1995, to December 31, 1995. Additionally, only one Mint facility in the United States can strike coins of a specific quality under this Act. The coins authorized under this Act shall be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value of the coins, plus surcharge. Bulk sales will be available at a reasonable discount. Prepaid orders will also be accepted by the Secretary. Bulk sales will be available at a reasonable discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted by the Secretary. All sales will include a surcharge of $10 per coin. General waiver of procurement regulations. No provision of law governing procurement or public contracts shall be applicable to the procurement of goods or services necessary for carrying out the provisions of this Act. Nothing in this section shall relieve any person entering into a contract under the authority of this Act from complying with any law relating to equal employment opportunity.

Distribution of surcharges. The Secretary shall promptly pay all surcharges received from the sale of coins issued under this Act to the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden. The Comptroller General has the right to examine the books, records, documents, and other data of the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden related to the expenditures of amounts paid under section 8. The Act may be cited as the "United States Botanic Garden Commemorative Coin Act of 1995". It specifies the coin details. The "United States Botanic Garden Commemorative Coin Act of 1995" authorizes the minting of up to 500,000 $1 coins made of 90% silver and 10% copper. The coins feature a design of a rose and the United States Botanic Garden facade, with inscriptions including "Liberty", "In God We Trust", and "E Pluribus Unum". The coins are legal tender as per section 5103 of title 31, United States Code. The coins minted under the "United States Botanic Garden Commemorative Coin Act of 1995" feature inscriptions of the year 1995, "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". These coins are legal tender and considered numismatic items. The Secretary must obtain silver for the coins from stockpiles under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. The design for the coins will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden and the Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee before issuance. The design for the coins minted under this Act will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden and the Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. The coins may be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities, struck at a single Mint facility, and can be issued between January 1, 1995, and December 31, 1995. The coins authorized under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price including face value, a surcharge, and design costs. Bulk sales will be available at a discount, prepaid orders accepted with a discount, and all sales will include a $10 surcharge per coin. Additionally, there is a general waiver of procurement regulations. SEC. 7. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. No procurement laws apply to goods and services for this Act, except for equal employment opportunity laws. SEC. 8. SURCHARGES DISTRIBUTION. Surcharges from coin sales go to the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden. SEC. 9. AUDITS. SEC. 8. Surcharges from coin sales under this Act are promptly paid to the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden. SEC. 9. The Comptroller General of the United States can audit the National Fund's expenditures related to these payments.
